Description: Bottle (incomplete). Lobed rim. Decorated with floral and vegetal motifs, seated human figures and prowling animals. Inscription in ring around the center of the bottle. Fritware (stonepaste); painted in lustre.
Curator's comments: Fragmentary fritware pot painted in lustre with seated figures and prowling animals. The poetic inscription round the body is followed by the date Muharram 575 AH/June 1179 AD The date makes this the earliest dated lustreware known, It was probably produced within a few years of the start of lustre production at Kashan, Iran. The inscription may be translated: 'Oh Heavenly sphere, why do you set affliction before me? Oh fortune, why do you scatter salt on my wounds? Oh Enemy of mine, how often will you strike at me? I am stuck by my own fate and fortune. May joy, exultation and cheerfulness be with you. May prosperity, happiness and triumph be your companions.' (Translation: O. Watson) Further reading: T. Pradell, J. Molera, A.D. Smith, and M.S. Tite, "Early Islamic Lustre from Egypt, Syria and Iran (10th to 13th Century AD)." Journal of Archaeological Science 35, no. 9 (2008): 2649-662.
